docs.lead_paragraph: On Election Day last month, Gerald M. Cohen, the chairman of the Massachusetts State Legislature's joint taxation committee, stood watch outside a polling place in an anxious attempt to predict the fate of Proposition 2 1/2, the nation's most sweeping tax-cut referendum. ''You could see how they were going to vote by the anger in their eyes,'' he said later that day, when 81 percent of the voters had turned out to approve the measure by a 2-to-1 margin. ''It was burn, baby, burn.'' Fed up after decades of less drastic attempts to reform the state's oppressive and chaotic tax structure, the voters approved a meat cleaver measure that will reduce municipal revenues by up to 70 percent in many communities and force major service cutbacks. Preliminary plans recently drawn up to implement the tax cuts in Boston, for example, call for a 30 percent reduction in the city's operating budget for the fiscal year beginning in July, and 30 percent cutbacks in each of the two succeeding years as the city attempts to gradually reduce its property tax level from 10 percent of fair market value to 2 1/2 percent, as mandated by the new law.
